text:
Does the Electoral College Work?

The Electoral College is a system in the United States in which the president and vice president are elected not by a direct popular vote, but by electors chosen by each state. This system has been in place since the 1780s, and it has been the subject of much debate ever since. Some argue that the Electoral College is an outdated system that should be abolished, while others believe that it is a necessary part of American democracy.

There are several arguments in favor of the Electoral College. First, it ensures that all states have a say in the presidential election, regardless of their population. Without the Electoral College, it is possible that a candidate could win the popular vote by a landslide but still lose the election because they did not win enough states. This would effectively disenfranchise voters in smaller states, who would have no say in who became president.

Second, the Electoral College helps to prevent the rise of third parties. In a direct popular vote system, third parties would have a much better chance of winning elections. This could lead to a splintering of the political system, making it more difficult to govern.

Third, the Electoral College provides a check on the power of the presidency. The president is the most powerful person in the United States, and the Electoral College helps to ensure that they are not too powerful. By requiring the president to win a majority of electoral votes, the Electoral College makes it more difficult for them to act unilaterally.

However, there are also several arguments against the Electoral College. First, it can lead to a situation where a candidate can win the presidency without winning the popular vote. This happened in 2016, when Donald Trump won the Electoral College but lost the popular vote to Hillary Clinton by nearly 3 million votes. This situation can be seen as undemocratic, as it means that the president does not represent the majority of the people.

Second, the Electoral College gives too much power to swing states. In recent elections, a few key swing states, such as Florida and Ohio, have decided the outcome of the election. This means that the votes of people in these states are worth more than the votes of people in other states. This can be seen as unfair, as it means that the people in swing states have a disproportionate amount of influence over the outcome of the election.

Third, the Electoral College can be manipulated by gerrymandering. Gerrymandering is the process of drawing electoral districts in a way that gives one political party an advantage. This can be used to create "safe" districts, in which one party is almost guaranteed to win, and "swing" districts, in which the outcome is less certain. By manipulating the electoral map, it is possible to give one party an advantage in the Electoral College, even if they do not have the support of a majority of the voters.

In conclusion, there are both pros and cons to the Electoral College. It is a complex system that has been the subject of much debate. Ultimately, it is up to the American people to decide whether or not the Electoral College should be abolished.

Some people like to drive while others don't and some countries are making bans or just limiting the usage of cars. This can have more advantages than disadvantages.

When people drive cars they let out pollution into the air which harms the atmosphere. The advantages to this is that if people don't drive that much anymore the pollution can be stopped at a certain point and cause no harm anymore of course the air might still be polluted but with a less perentage. People would definitely use money on something else thtne to try and get the new car or just use it on gas. There are alternatives to limit the use of cars.

sociologists believe if this continues with people limiting car transportation that "it will have beneficial implications for carbon emissions and the environment, since transportation is the second largest source of America's emission, just behind power plants." so if we all got to think about it we are basically doing a favor to ourselves by helping the planet by limiting the use of cars.

Another advantage that this idea might have is that the people in the community could stop spending more money due to cuts in the job. They waste money on gas on new cars, etc. When really you could be doing something better with that money.

Most poeple dont even really need cars they use them for the heck of it. Teenagers use it just to go around with friends or go to work but really they could limit that use and find another way of transportation. This isn't saying to just stop using your car but just finding a way to say that if you dont really need your car but just using it for fun then you could limit that use and instead of driving to places that are close to you just walk there.

The author of "The End of Car Culture" elisabeth Rosenthal even said that her own kids being 19 and 21 "have not even bothered to get a driver's license...." they find other ways to get around she said "they organize their summer jobs and social life around where they can walk or take public transportation or carpool with friends" as i said before there are alternatives to limiting the usage of cars and this could be one of them if you are with friends and all are going to the same palce then you ca just share one car so that not all of the cars are ut it can avoid traffic and cost less money to you also.

In conclusion, I say that there are alot of advantages to limiting the use of cars and we could most definitely make more.

The electoral college has many inherent flaws that make it less desirable than a simple election by popular vote. It's only rebuttal to said flaws are weak, and provide little to no reason why the college is beneficial. So there is no real reason to have it in the first place. Popular vote stands to not only correct the errors of the electoral college, but also to refine our voting system. It would accomplish this by closer to a real democracy, and forcing the candidates to win over more people.

A democracy has long been revered as one of the best forms of government. It is more liberating than a dictatorship or monarchy in which people are governed by a higher class, which is more often than not decided by someone other than themselves. In a democracy however, people are given the ability to put who they desire in office. They have the ability to be governed by the person of their choice. This, however, is impeded upon by the electoral college. Because what it does is simply insert a middle man into an otherwise democratic society. We are forced to rely on people we elect to vote for us. Which is irrational as it is completely unnecessary. The extra step only sets us up for deception and betrayal. I mean why would you trust a man on the street to cast a vote for you when doing so yourself is much more reliable?

Though why does it even matter if the candidate you want to vote for won't even come to your state? There's obviously no reason to vote democrat if your say will simply be overshadowed by the wave of republicans in your area. With popular vote though, candidates should be more inclined to visit as many states as possible and get their message out there. Because a 51% vote in a state no longer means a 100% victory. With the new influx of political campaigns, perhaps more people are swayed from their usual path of voting. While yes, there are neutral states that need a push either way, you're not going to increase your votes tenfold by pushing past that 50% barrier. You actually have to earn every vote you get.

There is no real reason to keep the electoral college. It serves as a pointless middle man to an otherwise great government. Popular vote requires more out of the candidates, and puts more say into the individual vote.

Recently, in many countries around the world, there have been actions made towards the reduction or complete banishment of most automobiles in order to help advance society. In Paris, there was a law enacted forcing drivers to leave their cars at home every other day. A majority of the reasoning behind such a ban was the pollution that were constantly emitted into the atmosphere. This is not only accepted by the general public, but some even say that their stress was much lower than with automobiles in daily life.

The people who give up their vehicles to live in Vauban, Germany report having less stress than when they did use cars as daily transportation. As stated by Heidrun Walter, a media trainer who lives in Vauban, "When I had a car I was always tense. I'm much happier this way." In this experimental suburban community, places to park a car are forbidden in most areas. They go as far as to rid of all driveways and parking lots in the community. This creates more spaces or businesses to operate, causing all stores to be built closer to households. This in turn makes getting to and from places faster and safer. The people in Paris also prefer the decreased amount of vehicles during rush hour, which alleviates their stress tremendously when navigating the city. This has affected less major cities also, such as Bogota. Their annual carfree day has lead to the construction of over 118 miles of bicycle paths, which is the longest amount in any Latin country. Not only that, but other recreational activity centers have also emerged throughout the city, according the mayor of Bogota.

Pollution has had a large impact in large, carintensified cities like Paris, which was, at some points, comparable to places with the most pollution. The smog eventually resided, but some aspects of the ban still remained. The cars there typically use diesel over gasoline due to tax policies that prefer it specifically. Thus, about two thirds of the vehicles in France prefer diesel engines, which are to blame for the smog that engulfed Paris. According the New York Times, Passenger cars in Europe are responsible for twelve percent of the total greenhouse emissions. The percentage in the United States is over four times that in some congested areas.

The cities of Paris, Vauban, and Bogota are few of the many global areas that have taken on the challenge of removing cars from their daily lives, which has benefited both their health and their environment. This is a part of the longterm shift in our societies' way of commuting from one place to another. The amount of people going to get driver licesnses has been on a decline since 2005 in the United States, and is projected the continue that path for a long time. In fact, there was a twenty three percent decrease in young poeple driving form 2001 to 2009. People are alreading seeing the benefits of decreasing the use of cars, and the amount of traffic is only going to keep decreasing. As a local businessman in Bogota said, "It's a good opportunity to take away stress and lower air pollution.

Dear Senator...

The electoral college has recently been a very controversial topic in the world of politics. Many believe that it's a significant system, that's why the Founding Fathers created it, while others argue that it doesn't necessarily work as well. The Electoral College is a process in which there is an agreement between the president's election by a vote in Congress and the president's election by a popular vote made by the citizens. There should be a change in the system into changing election by a popular vote since the Electoral College is not only an outdated system, but it gives the citizens no control over who Congress will be picking.

To start off, the process of the Electoral College should be changed since it's an outdated system. As stated in "In Defense of the Electoral College" it says "The Electoral College is widely regarded as anachroism, a non democratic method of selecting a president that ought to be overruled by declaring the candidate who receives the most popular votes the winner." Even the article that seems to be favoring the electoral college introduced it as so. It can be seen that it is a process that has been around since America itself, but America has constantly been changing and innovating and it needs a more flexible system to cast the votes. In "What is the Electoral College"? it states that "THE FOUNDING FATHERS ESTABLISHED IT IN THE CONSTITUTION AS QA COMPROMISE" HENCE THIS IS STATING THAT THE SYSTEM WAS CREATED A LONG TIME AGO AND IT NEEDS SOME CHANGES.

TO CONTINUE, THE ELECTORAL COLLEGE SYSTEM SHOULD BE ALTERED SINCE IT DOESN'T GIVE THE CITIZENS ALOT OF CONTROL AS TO WHO THE CONGRESS WILL BE PICKING. IN "THE INDEFENSIBLE ELECTORAL COLLEGE, IT SAYS THAT 'THE SINGLE BEST ARGUMENT AGAINST THE ELECTORAL COLLEGE IS WHAT WE MIGHT CALL THE DISASTER FACTOR." WHAT THIS IS, IS THAT THE VOTERS HAVE NO CONTROL WHOM THE ELECTORS VOTE FOR. AS WELL, IN THE SAME ARTICLE, IT STATES THAT "AT THE MOST BASIC LEVEL, THE ELECTORAL COLLEGE IS UNFAIR TO VOTERS. BECAUSE OF THE WINNER TAKE ALL SYSTEM IN EACH STATE, CANDIDATES DON'T SPEND TIME IN STATES THEY KNOW THEY HAVE NO CHNACE OF WINNING." WHAT ALL THIS SAYS IS THAT, THE VOTERS HAVE NO IDEA WHO THE ELECTORAL COLLEGE IS PICKING, AND IT SHOULD BE CHANGED TO ANOTHER SYSTEM.

TO CONCLUDE, THE ELECTORAL SYSTEM SHOULD BE ALTERED TO A NEW SYSETM WHICH IS FAIR AND MORE TRUSTFUL TO THE VOTERS. NOT ONLY IS THE SYSTEM OUTDADE, BUT IT DOESN'T GIVE THE VOTERS ALOT OF CONTROL. A NEW SYSTEM SHOULD BE INTRODUCED. ALTHOUGH MANY AGREE THAT IT SHOULD BE CHANGED, ALSO SOME BELIEVE IT SHOULD STAY HOW IT IS. THE ELECTORAL COLLEGE SYSTEM SHOULD BE ALTERED, SO THIS WAY, THE PEOPLE HAVE THE VOICE, NOT ONLY THE GOVERNMENT.

Throughout the past century car usage has exploded from a luxury available only to the highest echelon of society to a tool almost essential to life. Although cars are convenient there are many downsides to having them. Some reasons a society that limits car use could be beneficial are: expenses, environmental costs, and health degredation. Hopefully together we can curb car usage and lead the way for a cheaper, greener, and healthier future.

Its a known fact that cars are expensive, but when you add up all of the costs how much is really spent. Especially for younger drivers insurance is a ludicrous expense, often totalling hundreds of dollars per month. Another expense, obviously, is gas. Gas may be at a 5 year low right now but the slightest instability in oil producing countries could cause prices to skyrocket. Still if you add in the cost of the car your looking at a highly expensive way of living. Life obviously could be less expensive without car use.

Another illeffect of car use is environmental impact. car emissions are responsible for up to 50 percent of total green house gas emissions in some states. Using cars is not good for the environment. Cars pollute are atmosphere and can accelerate the rate of ozone layer deterioration. They also, indirectly, damage habitats by requiring new roads and highways to be built thus disturbing ecosystems. Automobiles also use large quantities of petroleum a finite and ever necessary resource in this global world. Car usage needs to be drastically reduced in order to preserve the environment.

Health issues can also develop from overusing cars. For instance, by looking at cultures that do not use cars it is evident that less children with autism are born to said peoples, such as the Amish. Another benefit of not using cars is exercise. People that drive instead of walking or bicycling are not only becoming more obese they are also putting themselves at an elevated risk for heart disease. Car accidents are one of the highest causes of premature death in the united states thus if people drove less these accidents would occur far less often. The choice seems clear a carless society is more healthy for all.

All in all, although cars may have benefits, the drawbacks of having them far out way any of said benefits. Car usage is expensive, bad for the environment and unhealthy. Together, society must ultimately decide whether life with automobiles is worth it and live with the consequences.

Advantages of Limiting Car Usage

Limiting car usage can have numerous advantages for both individuals and the environment. This is increasingly becoming a global trend, as countries and communities recognize the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote sustainable living. The passage set provides examples from various cities and regions that have implemented measures to limit car usage and reap the benefits.

One primary advantage of limiting car usage is the reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. The passage states that passenger cars are responsible for a significant portion of these emissions, with Europe seeing 12 percent and some areas in the United States up to 50 percent. By reducing the number of cars on the road and promoting alternative transportation methods, such as walking, biking, and public transportation, communities can significantly decrease their carbon footprint and contribute to a cleaner environment.

Additionally, limiting car usage can lead to a decrease in traffic congestion. The passage describes how Paris implemented a driving ban due to smog, resulting in a 60 percent reduction in congestion. This not only improves air quality but also improves the efficiency of transportation in cities. With fewer cars on the road, public transportation can operate more smoothly, allowing people to reach their destinations faster.

Furthermore, limiting car usage can lead to healthier and more vibrant communities. The passage on Vauban, Germany, highlights the benefits of creating car-free neighborhoods. In this community, 70 percent of families do not own cars, and 57 percent sold their cars to move there. Residents enjoy the peace and quiet of car-free streets, with the swish of bicycles and the chatter of children replacing the noise of motors. This promotes an active lifestyle, as walking and biking become the primary modes of transportation. It also creates a sense of community, as people have more opportunities to interact with each other while walking or cycling.

Another advantage of limiting car usage is the potential for economic savings. The passage mentions that Vauban only allows for two places to park cars, which cost $40,000 each. While this may seem costly, it can lead to long-term savings for individuals and communities. By relying less on cars, people can save money on fuel, insurance, maintenance, and parking fees. Additionally, communities can invest the money saved from parking spaces in creating more pedestrian-friendly spaces, improving public transportation systems, and developing amenities like parks and sports centers.

In conclusion, limiting car usage has numerous advantages for both individuals and communities. It can significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions, decrease traffic congestion, promote healthier lifestyles, and lead to economic savings. The passage set provides examples from various cities and regions that have embraced these advantages and implemented measures to limit car usage. As the world continues to prioritize sustainability and environmental responsibility, it is crucial for more communities to consider limiting car usage for a better future.

The Electoral College should be not be abolished and the government should not change to election by popular vote for the President of the United States. The Electoral College requires the presidential candidate to have a transregional appeal, it produces a clear winner and avoids runoff elections, and the Electoral College allows people in swing states to be more thoughtful and choose wisely because the popular vote could be in their hands.

In Defense of the Electoral College: Five reasons to keep our despised method of choosing the President, it states, "The Electoral College requires a presidential candidate to have transregional appeal. No region South, Northeast, etc. has enough electoral votes to elect a president." This means that the favorite candidate of a particular region has no reason to campaign too much in those states because that candidate doesn't gain many more votes. Any candidate with only regional appeal is unlikely to be successful because the people of the other region feel that their interests will be overlooked by the president.

The Electoral College decreases the amount of pressure of a runoff election. In paragraph twentytwo of the article In Defense of the Electoral College: Five reasons to keep our despised method of choosing the President, it states, "The Electoral College avoids the problem of elections in which no candidate receives a majority of the votes cast." So if both presidential candidates receive an equal percent of of popular votes, the Electoral College's number of votes could be the "game changer." The number of votes in the Electoral College produces a clear winner. If there wasn't an Electoral College, then there would have to be a recount of votes and one vote could change the entire election. This could cause chaos in swing states because of the one vote of someone that might not even care who wins the election.

Based on many elections, the Electoral College creates more thoughtful voters in swing states. Those people know that the power of turning an election around is in their hands, so they must use that knowledge wisely, not recklessly. People in nonswing states will vote on a candidate that their peers like or that they heard is "the best" even though it may actually be a choice reconsidered two years into the winning candidates presidency. In paragraph twenty of the article In Defense of the Electoral College: Five reasons to keep our despised method of choosing the President, it states, "Voters in tossup states are more likely to pay close attention to the campaign, to really listen to the competeing candidates, knowing that they are going to decide the election." The most careful voters should be the ones to decide because they are the ones receiving the most attention by candidates trying to persuade them to vote for them.

Overall, the Electoral College should not be abolished and the government should not change to election by popular vote for the President of the United States. The Electoral College doesn't allow a presidential candidate to have a single regional appeal, it produces a clear and fair winner and avoids runoff elections, and the Electoral College creates more thoughtful and careful voters, because when you actually think choices through in life, it could make a tremendous impact on yourself everyone around you.

Limiting the usage of cars has a variety of advantages. From having a less expensive life, to less air pollution, and overall a generally happier life. Thinking about all the excess and stress that comes with owning a car is tiring. Not to mention the hazardous effect it had on our lives. Would it not be nice to just take off some of that burden off of you, and be a happier person?.Let me help you out on how to achieve that.

Owning a car is pricey! In Freiburg along with paying for your house you also have to pay for a parking garage, which comes with a hefty price. Did i not mention the distance you have to walk to park? lets just say you might as well have taken the bus."Car ownership is allowed, but there are only two places to parklarge garages at the edge of the development,where a carowner buys a space, for 40,000, along with a home."source one,section two. With you alone driving to work and back everyday will tally up to over a hundred dollars spent every week, now add children into it, and their after school activities, also add emergencies. See where this is going? sure you might need a car now and then, having a car is not a bad thing. How about Carpooling? It will reduce that price you have on your gas recipts and create more time for bonding and interacting with people.

Health or driving? Well if you are not healthy you can not drive can you? With all of the automobiles we have today it is bound to affect the earth. The smog in the air leading to that first cough that can lead to something more terminal. Imagine what it would be like if you had less cars, or even no cars at all! well the capital of France tried it and the results were amazing."Congestion was down 60 percent in the capital of France, after fivedays of intensifying smog.."source two,section fourteen. Now think about if that ban that Paris enforced,was tried out in other countries. Just that little change in the amount of cars on the road let to that difference of the pollution. Probably led to a difference in someones health too.

Everything stated above leads to happiness, from the less expenses that will have to be paid, and the less damage that the pollution will have on your health. "When I had a car I was always tense. I'm much happier this way," said Heidrun Walter"source one, section three.Also when there are less cars on the road your community will be able to connect more and have better infranstructure, which would make them happy just like it did for the people of Bogata, Columbia."Parks and sports centers also have bloomed throughout the city uneven, pitted sidewalks have been replaced by broad, smooth sidewalksrushhour restrictions have dramatically cut trafficand new resturants and upscale shopping districts have been cropped up."source three,section twentyeight.

Overall the advantages of limiting car usage has many benefits to it. From having a less expensive life, by not having to pay for gas so often, car insurance, and evrything else that comes with it. Having better health also is a advantage of the limitation of car usage. Also one of the most important aspects of life, happiness comes with the limitation of using cars. So there is no reason to not try it out, there will be more benefits.

Does the Electoral College Work? Examining the Pros and Cons
The United States' electoral system is a unique one, with its roots in the country's founding principles. The Electoral College, a body of electors chosen by each state, plays a crucial role in determining the outcome of the presidential election. However, this system has been the subject of much debate, with proponents arguing for its continued relevance and critics calling for its reform or abolition. In this essay, we will explore the pros and cons of the Electoral College system, examining its impact on the democratic process and the fairness of presidential elections.

Pros of the Electoral College:

1. Balance of Powers: The Electoral College helps to balance the power between large and small states. In a direct popular vote system, candidates would primarily focus their efforts on winning the votes of the most populous states, neglecting the needs and concerns of smaller states. The Electoral College ensures that all states have a say in the presidential election, regardless of their size.

2. State Autonomy: The Electoral College respects the principle of state sovereignty. Each state is free to determine the manner in which its electors are chosen, allowing for variations in voting systems and procedures. This allows states to tailor their electoral process to reflect their unique circumstances and values.

3. Prevents Voter Fraud: Proponents argue that the Electoral College makes it more difficult for widespread voter fraud to occur. With each state having its own set of election laws and procedures, it is more challenging for fraudulent activities to go undetected or be manipulated on a national level.

Cons of the Electoral College:

1. Undemocratic System: Critics argue that the Electoral College is inherently undemocratic as it does not directly reflect the popular vote. It is possible for a candidate to win the presidency without winning the majority of the popular vote, as was the case in the 2000 and 2016 elections. This can lead to a situation where the president does not represent the will of the majority of the American people.

2. Disenfranchisement of Minorities: The Electoral College system has been criticized for disenfranchising minority voters. In states where the popular vote is not competitive, minority voters may have little influence on the outcome of the election, as their votes are effectively diluted. This can lead to a lack of representation for minority communities in the political process.

3. Winner-Take-All System: The winner-take-all system used in most states means that the candidate who wins the most votes in a state receives all of the state's electoral votes, even if they only win by a narrow margin. This system can lead to situations where a candidate can win the presidency with a small number of decisive victories in key swing states, while losing the popular vote by a significant margin.

Conclusion:

The Electoral College remains a contentious issue in American politics, with strong arguments on both sides. Proponents emphasize the system's ability to balance power, respect state sovereignty, and prevent voter fraud. On the other hand, critics argue that it is undemocratic, disenfranchises minority voters, and produces unrepresentative outcomes. Ultimately, the decision of whether to reform or abolish the Electoral College is a complex one that requires careful consideration of the potential benefits and drawbacks of each option.

The United States' presidential election system is unique in that it relies on the Electoral College rather than the direct popular vote. This system, established in the Constitution, has been a subject of ongoing debate, with arguments both for and against its continued use. While the Electoral College has several advantages, it also has significant drawbacks that raise questions about its effectiveness in ensuring a fair and representative election process.

One of the main arguments in favor of the Electoral College is that it protects the interests of small states. In a direct popular vote system, large states with concentrated populations would have a disproportionate influence on the outcome of the election. The Electoral College, however, allocates votes based on a state's population, ensuring that small states have a voice in the electoral process. This feature of the Electoral College is seen as a safeguard against the dominance of a few large states and promotes a more balanced representation of the nation's interests.

Another advantage of the Electoral College is that it encourages candidates to campaign in all parts of the country, not just in the most populous states. In a direct popular vote system, candidates would likely focus their efforts on a few large states, where they could secure the most votes. This would lead to a situation where rural areas and small states would be neglected, as candidates would have little incentive to campaign in these regions. The Electoral College, by requiring candidates to win a majority of electoral votes, ensures that they must appeal to a broader cross-section of the electorate and consider the interests of all states.

However, despite these advantages, the Electoral College also has several drawbacks that raise concerns about its fairness and legitimacy. One of the most significant criticisms of the Electoral College is that it can lead to a situation where a candidate wins the presidency despite losing the popular vote. This has happened on five occasions in U.S. history, most recently in 2016 when Donald Trump won the presidency despite losing the popular vote to Hillary Clinton by nearly 3 million votes. This outcome has led to accusations that the Electoral College is undemocratic and does not accurately reflect the will of the people.

Another criticism of the Electoral College is that it can lead to a "winner-takes-all" system, where the candidate who wins the most votes in a state takes all of that state's electoral votes. This system can result in a situation where a candidate wins the presidency with a relatively small number of votes, as long as they win a majority of electoral votes. This can lead to a situation where a candidate who does not have the support of the majority of the population can still become president.

Furthermore, the Electoral College can be subject to gerrymandering, where political boundaries are drawn in a way that benefits a particular party or candidate. This can lead to a situation where the distribution of electoral votes is skewed in favor of one party, making it more difficult for the other party to win the presidency.

In conclusion, while the Electoral College has several advantages, such as protecting the interests of small states and encouraging candidates to campaign in all parts of the country, it also has significant drawbacks that raise concerns about its fairness and legitimacy. The potential for a candidate to win the presidency despite losing the popular vote, the winner-takes-all system, and the possibility of gerrymandering are all issues that need to be addressed. Whether the Electoral College should be reformed or replaced with a direct popular vote system is a complex issue with strong arguments on both sides. Ultimately, it is up to the American people to decide whether the Electoral College continues to serve the best interests of the nation.

Dear Senator,

I am writing to advocate for an important representation issue: the Electoral College. As a constituent who deeply cares about the way our democracy operates, I believe it is critical to rethink this mechanism. I argue for a shift to a national popular vote system for presidential elections. 

The Electoral College, established as a compromise during the founding of our country, selects the President and Vice President (Office of the Federal Register). However, it does not necessarily align with the democratic principles of representation. Bradford Plumer and Judge Richard A. Posner discuss the potential flaws and merits of this system.

Plumer argues that the Electoral College is outdated, irrational, and has potential for disaster (Plumer 14). There could be confusion among voters about who they are actually voting for, and "faithless" electors could potentially betray the people's will (Plumer 10,11). In close elections, the vote could be thrown to the House of Representatives, where smaller states have disproportionate say, a result that would undemocratically represent the will of the people (Plumer 12). Furthermore, the focus on swing states leads to many states being ignored during campaigns (Plumer 13).

While Posner acknowledges these complexities, he provides five reasons to retain the Electoral College, such as the certainty of outcome, requiring trans-regional appeal for candidates, focusing efforts on swing states, and avoiding run-off elections (Posner 17-22). However, these reasons are largely practical considerations rather than principled bases.

While the Electoral College does produce a clear winner (Posner 22), it does not always reflect the popular vote, as shown by the elections of 2000 and 2016. Furthermore, the focus on swing states leaves many Americans feeling ignored during campaigns, undermining the argument that the Electoral College system supports voter attentiveness (Posner 20). 

A shift to a national popular vote would ensure that every vote casts equals impact, reducing the potential for disproportionate representation. There would be no need to worry about "faithless" electors defying the will of the people (Plumer 11). Furthermore, candidates would need to focus on appealing to voters across the nation, not just those in swing states, leading to broader inclusivity in campaigns.

However, it is important to consider possible complications of direct democracy, such as the potential for minority rights to be overridden by majority rule. 

The complexity of this issue calls for thorough research and evaluation. Therefore, I encourage your attention to this matter to ensure that our democracy accurately represents the will of the American people. 

Thank you for your time and consideration.

The Electoral College, a system rooted in the foundations of American democracy, has been a subject of ongoing debate and contention. Established by the framers of the Constitution, it serves as an intermediary body between popular vote and the election of the President of the United States. While the Electoral College has its merits, such as ensuring representation for smaller states and preventing an unqualified individual from attaining the presidency, it also presents several drawbacks that warrant consideration.

One of the primary arguments in favor of the Electoral College is its ability to protect the interests of smaller states. In a purely popular vote system, candidates would likely focus their campaigns on densely populated areas, neglecting the concerns and needs of rural states. The Electoral College, however, requires candidates to secure a majority of electoral votes, which are distributed among the states based on their population. This system incentivizes candidates to campaign in a broader range of states, including those with smaller populations, thus ensuring that their voices are heard and their interests are represented.

Furthermore, the Electoral College acts as a safeguard against the election of an unqualified or unfit individual to the presidency. In a popular vote system, a candidate with a narrow margin of victory could potentially become president, even if they do not receive the support of a majority of the population. The Electoral College, on the other hand, requires a candidate to win a majority of electoral votes, which makes it more difficult for a fringe candidate or someone with limited qualifications to attain the presidency.

However, the Electoral College also has several notable drawbacks that cannot be ignored. One of the most significant criticisms is that it allows for the possibility of a candidate winning the presidency while losing the popular vote. This scenario, known as an Electoral College victory without a popular vote majority, has occurred five times in American history, most recently in 2016 when Donald Trump won the presidency despite losing the popular vote to Hillary Clinton by nearly three million votes. This outcome raises concerns about the legitimacy and representativeness of the Electoral College, as it undermines the principle of majority rule, a cornerstone of democratic systems.

Moreover, the Electoral College disproportionately amplifies the influence of certain states, particularly swing states, which are states that are competitive in presidential elections and can swing either way. Candidates tend to focus their time and resources on these swing states, while neglecting states that are considered safe for either party. This dynamic can lead to a situation where the concerns and interests of voters in non-swing states are marginalized, further eroding the principle of equal representation.

In conclusion, while the Electoral College has certain advantages, such as protecting the interests of smaller states and preventing the election of unqualified candidates, its flaws, including the possibility of a president winning without the popular vote and the disproportionate influence of swing states, cannot be overlooked. These shortcomings raise questions about the fairness, representativeness, and democratic nature of the Electoral College. Ongoing debates and discussions about potential reforms or alternatives, such as a popular vote system or a proportional representation system, underscore the need to address the limitations of the current system and ensure that the election of the President of the United States truly reflects the will of the American people.

The Case for Limited Car Usage: Improving Environmental and Urban Health

The advantages of limiting car usage are manifold, promoting healthier societies as well as a more sustainable environment. The experiences of cities such as Vauban in Germany, Paris, and Bogota, in conjunction with emerging attitudes in the United States towards car ownership, underscore these benefits.

To understand the primary driver behind this shift, one must consider environmental concerns. Cars are a major source of greenhouse gas emissions; passenger cars account for 12 percent of such emissions in Europe and up to 50 percent in some areas in the U.S. (Rosenthal, "In German Suburb"). In order to curb these harmful emissions, some urban areas have started planning smart, low-car suburbs with limited parking spaces and improved access to public transportation. Vauban, a suburb in Germany, for instance, has successfully executed this model, with 70 percent of its residents opting not to own cars (Rosenthal, "In German Suburb").

The experience of Paris offers a stark cautionary tale of high car dependency. In response to a severe smog crisis, the French capital had to enforce a partial driving ban, causing considerable disruption but resulting in a significant decrease in air pollution (Duffer). The driving ban also underscored the potentially salutary effects of limiting car usage on urban air quality, as seen in other cities as well. 

As Colombians have demonstrated, limiting car usage doesn’t mean giving up a mobile lifestyle entirely. During Bogota’s “Day Without Cars,” millions of residents turned to bikes and public transportation for commuting, effectively reducing air pollutants while promoting physical health and community solidarity (Selsky).

Meanwhile, in the United States, a cultural shift appears to be under way with increasing numbers of Americans buying fewer cars and driving less frequently (Rosenthal, "The End of Car Culture"). This cultural change isn't solely rooted in environmental concerns; improved urban planning, the rise in telecommuting, and better access to public transportation have also contributed to the shift (Rosenthal, "The End of Car Culture").

All these examples underline the multiple advantages of limiting car usage. Not only does this lead to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, it also fosters healthier, more vibrant urban communities. By making the choice to drive less, citizens can contribute to the well-being of their cities and the planet, encouraging a sustainable lifestyle for the future generations. By supporting policies that promote alternative modes of transportation and planning smart, low-car suburban lives, we can accelerate this beneficial transition. In the balance are not just our suburbs and cities but also the planet's future.

The advantages of limiting car usage are becoming increasingly clear as cities and communities around the world experiment with new approaches to transportation. One such example is Vauban, a suburb in Germany where cars are not allowed on the streets except for a few designated areas. This experiment has led to numerous benefits for the residents, including reduced greenhouse gas emissions, improved air quality, and a sense of community and livability.

According to an article in the New York Times, cars are responsible for 12 percent of greenhouse gas emissions in Europe and up to 50 percent in some car-intensive areas in the United States. By limiting car usage, communities like Vauban can make a significant impact on reducing these emissions. The article also mentions that Vauban's streets are peaceful and quiet, with the swish of bicycles and the sound of children playing replacing the noise of car engines.

In addition to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, limiting car usage can also improve air quality. Paris, for example, implemented a partial driving ban during a period of smog, resulting in a 60 percent decrease in congestion and a noticeable improvement in air quality. The ban targeted even-numbered license plates one day and odd-numbered plates the next, and nearly 4,000 drivers were fined for violating the ban. While there were complaints from delivery companies about lost revenue, exceptions were made for plug-in cars, hybrids, and cars with three or more passengers.

Another example of the benefits of limiting car usage can be seen in Bogota, Colombia, which has implemented a car-free day for the past three years. This day encourages alternative forms of transportation such as walking, biking, and public transportation. The event has been successful in reducing traffic congestion and promoting a healthier and more sustainable lifestyle. Other cities in Colombia have also joined in the event, and municipal authorities from other countries have come to witness and learn from the event.

The end of car culture is predicted by many experts, as Americans are buying fewer cars, driving less, and getting fewer licenses. This trend has environmental implications as transportation is the second-largest source of greenhouse gas emissions in the United States. With advancements in technology and changes in behavior, people are finding alternative means of getting around, such as telecommuting, shared van services, and bike-sharing programs. The decrease in driving by young people is particularly notable, with studies showing a 23 percent decrease between 2001 and 2009.

In conclusion, limiting car usage has numerous advantages, including reduced greenhouse gas emissions, improved air quality, and a shift towards a more sustainable and livable environment. The examples of Vauban, Paris, and Bogota show that it is possible to create thriving communities without cars, and that alternative modes of transportation can be successful and beneficial. As we continue to prioritize the environment and seek ways to reduce our carbon footprint, limiting car usage is a significant step in the right direction.

Dear Senator, I want to change to election by popular vote for the president of the United States because it is easier and makes a lot more sense. When you vote by the Electoral College, you are actually voting for your candidates electors. When you vote for the electors, it doesn't necessarily mean they will vote for their candidate. Voters can't always control who their electors vote for, as stated in "Can voters control whom their electors vote for? Not always." There is a single argument against the Electoral College is best known as the disaster factor. In 1960, segregationists who were in the Louisiana Legislature succeeded in replacing the Democratic electors with electors that would oppose John F. Kennedy. They did this so that a popular vote for Kennedy would not have actually gone to Kennedy. In almost the same way, "faithless" electors sometimes refuse to vote for their party's candidate. Instead they cast a deciding vote for whoever they want.

The electors and segregationists in the Electoral College think they can do whatever they please. They make decisions that wouldn't be fair to the voters or the candidates. If the voter votes for a certain candidate but the elector votes for a different candidate, this could cause trouble and madness within the election. The Electoral College is not always fair. However, if we switch to the election of the popular votes, the election would be fair. The candidates would be chosen based on the number of votes they got from voters, not by who the electors want to vote for.

People also worry about the prospect of a tie in the Electoral College. If this happens, the election would be handed over to the House of Representatives. Then the state delegations would vote on the president. In this case, the Senate would choose the vicepresident."Because each state casts only one vote, the single representative in Wyoming, representing 500,000 voters, would have as much say as the 55 representatives from California, who represent 35 million voters". From this context, we can say that the House's selection can barely be expected to reflect the will of the people.

I think the Electoral College is not accurate and the electors in it are not very fair. If someone elects a certain candidate, but the elector votes for someone else, there really isn't a purpose for people to vote. If people don't vote, then our country won't have a president. The Electoral College can take this country downhill in several ways. We should let the people decide who they want to run their country. That way, the voting will be more fair, easier, and not as many bad things could happen while the process of voting is going on. I think the Electoral College should not be the way that our country's citizens should vote by.

Do you know what pollution is? Have you ever taken a trip by car? Well, cars emit a significant and substantial amount of pollution into the atmosphere. Such pollution will result in a damaged atmosphere. Therefore, it is important to decrease car usage, because there are several advantages that will arise from limiting car usage.

To begin with, limiting car usage will decrease the amount of pollution in the atmosphere which will result in cleaner air and healthier cities. In "Paris bans driving due to smog," Robert Duffer writes, "After days of nearrecord pollution, paris enforced a partial driving ban to clear the air of the global city." Overusing cars in the metropolis had caused the air to become extremely and dangerously polluted. The pollution had resulted in smog, a mixture of fog and pollution from cars that is very harmful. The partial driving ban that was enacted in Paris had positive effects in the city, because after one week of the partial driving ban, the smog had cleared and the ban was rescinded for certain cars. While the ban in Paris was a way to handle the destructive pollution from cars in the city, there are only a handful of regulations that are in place towards making cities less polluted. For example, in India the air is polluted to the point where one can see the pollution that resulted from smoke from cars. In the carintensive areas of the United States, passenger cars are responsible from up to 50 percent of greenhouse gas emissions. It is imperative that more regulations are enacted in the most dangerous and polluted cities. Cleaner air can only be achieved by limiting car usage around the world, especially in the most carintensive and polluted parts of the world.

The reconstruction of the ozone layer will result from limiting car usage around the world. Burning fossil fuels and cars emitting greenhouse gases have damaged the atmosphere in a colossal way. Greenhouse gases have been exponentially breaking down our atmosphere. As cars are continuously overused in many parts of the world, the danger of radiation increases as well. The connection between the destruction of the atmosphere and increases of greenhouse gases of the atmosphere will continue to be increasing until several actions are taken to prevent such disasters. In "In German Suburb, Life Goes On Without Cars," some cities and towns have also gone as far as having suburbs where there are barely any cars in the streets. In such cities, the air is cleaner, people are healthier and there is air pollution as well as noise pollution. Unless we make more efforts to limit car usage around the world, the planet will be plagued by a poor atmosphere, irradiated locations and unhealthy people.

Finally, while cars are being overused around the world, there are a handful of efforts being done to protect our planet from pollution. People must be informed of the consequences of too much car usage. Even though there are just a handful of regulations decreasing air pollution, people must continue to limit car usage in order to receive positive effects.

The Electoral College, a distinctive feature of the United States' presidential election process, has been a subject of ongoing debate. It is a system in which electors, chosen by each state, cast their votes to determine the president and vice president. While the Electoral College has several advantages, it also has significant drawbacks. This essay will explore both the pros and cons of the Electoral College system.

One of the primary advantages of the Electoral College is its ability to protect the interests of small states. In a direct popular vote system, where the candidate with the most popular votes wins, the concerns and needs of small states could be easily overlooked. The Electoral College ensures that each state has a say in the presidential election, regardless of its population size. This system gives smaller states a disproportionate influence in the election outcome, as each state's electoral votes are determined by its population, with a minimum of three votes. This can be seen as a safeguard against the interests of large, populous states dominating the election.

Another advantage of the Electoral College is that it encourages candidates to campaign in a wider range of states. In a direct popular vote system, candidates would likely focus their efforts on the most populous states, where they could garner the most votes. However, the Electoral College system requires candidates to compete for electoral votes in a variety of states, including those that may not be considered traditional swing states. This can lead to a more inclusive and representative election process.

However, the Electoral College system also has several drawbacks. One of the most significant criticisms is that it can lead to a situation where a candidate can win the presidency without winning the popular vote. This occurred in the 2016 election, when Donald Trump became president despite losing the popular vote to Hillary Clinton by nearly 3 million votes. This outcome can be seen as undemocratic, as it allows a candidate to become president even though they did not receive the support of the majority of American voters.

Another disadvantage of the Electoral College is that it can disenfranchise voters in certain states. In states that consistently vote for one party, the votes of the minority party's supporters may not matter, as the state's electoral votes will likely go to the candidate of the majority party regardless of the popular vote outcome within that state. This can lead to feelings of disenfranchisement and a lack of representation for voters in these states.

Furthermore, the Electoral College system can make it difficult for third-party and independent candidates to gain traction. In a direct popular vote system, these candidates would have a better chance of winning if they could garner enough votes nationwide. However, the Electoral College system makes it challenging for third-party candidates to win electoral votes, as they typically do not have the resources or support to compete effectively in multiple states.

In conclusion, the Electoral College system has both advantages and disadvantages. While it protects the interests of small states and encourages candidates to campaign in a wider range of states, it can also lead to a situation where a candidate can win the presidency without winning the popular vote. Additionally, it can disenfranchise voters in certain states and make it difficult for third-party and independent candidates to gain traction. Ultimately, the question of whether the Electoral College works is a complex one with no easy answer.

Dear,

I am writing to express my views on the Electoral College and to argue in favor of keeping this system for electing the President of the United States. While it is true that there are arguments against the Electoral College, there are also several compelling reasons to retain this method.

One of the main advantages of the Electoral College is the certainty of outcome that it provides. Despite the occasional dispute over the outcome, as seen in the 2000 election, the electoral vote winner generally aligns with the winner of the popular vote. This ensures that the candidate who receives the most support across various states is elected as President. The winner-take-all system in most states helps to create a landslide victory for the winning candidate, reducing the likelihood of a tie in the nationwide electoral vote.

Additionally, the Electoral College promotes the concept of "Everyone's President." With its requirement for a candidate to have trans-regional appeal, the system prevents a candidate with only regional favor from being elected. This encourages presidential candidates to campaign across different regions, thereby representing the interests of a diverse range of constituents. It ensures that no particular region has an undue influence over the election outcome, fostering a sense of inclusivity among voters.

Another benefit of the Electoral College is its focus on swing states. The winner-take-all approach encourages candidates to concentrate their campaign efforts on states where the outcome is uncertain. By doing so, they engage voters in those states more effectively, leading to higher voter participation and informed decision-making. Furthermore, swing states are more likely to have the most thoughtful voters who closely follow the campaign and have a substantial impact on the election result.

The Electoral College also serves to balance the power between large and small states. By awarding electoral votes based on population, it presents an opportunity for states with larger populations to receive more attention from presidential candidates. This prevents lesser-populated states from being neglected or overshadowed, ensuring that their voices are heard during the campaign and considered in the election outcome.

Lastly, the Electoral College avoids the need for run-off elections when no candidate receives a majority of the popular votes. This feature provides for a clear and decisive winner, preventing extended and potentially contentious election processes. The Electoral College has consistently produced a definitive outcome, which helps to maintain stability and efficiency in the presidential election process.

While some argue that the Electoral College discourages voters in states where their preferred candidate has no hope of winning, the high voter turnout in recent elections suggests otherwise. Many voters recognize the importance of expressing their political preferences, regardless of the potential impact on the national election. Moreover, the Electoral College serves as a safeguard against the potential influence of a few swing voters in determining the fate of the presidency, ensuring a more balanced and representative outcome.

In conclusion, the Electoral College provides several practical reasons for its retention. Its inherent advantages, such as certainty of outcome, trans-regional appeal, focus on swing states, balance between large and small states, and avoidance of run-off elections, make it a sensible and efficient method for electing the President. I urge you to consider these points when deciding on the future of this system.

Thank you for your attention to this important matter.

The Electoral College, a system rooted in the foundations of American democracy, has been a subject of ongoing debate and contention. Established by the framers of the Constitution, it serves as an intermediary body between popular vote and the election of the President and Vice President of the United States. While it has been lauded for its ability to protect the interests of smaller states and ensure stability in the political system, the Electoral College has also faced criticism for its potential to subvert the will of the people and produce outcomes that do not reflect the popular vote.

The primary argument in favor of the Electoral College is that it helps to protect the interests of smaller states. In a purely popular vote system, candidates would focus their efforts on securing votes in densely populated urban areas, largely ignoring the concerns and needs of rural communities. The Electoral College, by allocating votes to each state based on its population, ensures that every state has a voice in the presidential election. This system encourages candidates to campaign in all regions of the country, taking into account the diverse perspectives and interests of the American people.

Another argument supporting the Electoral College is that it promotes stability and prevents radical shifts in political power. Under a popular vote system, a candidate could win the presidency with a narrow margin of victory in a few large states, potentially leading to a situation where a significant portion of the population feels unrepresented or marginalized. The Electoral College, by requiring candidates to secure a majority of electoral votes, creates a higher threshold for victory. This encourages candidates to build broad coalitions of support and seek consensus on important issues, fostering a more stable and inclusive political process.

However, the Electoral College is not without its critics. One of the most significant criticisms is that it can lead to outcomes that do not reflect the will of the majority. In the 2016 presidential election, for instance, Donald Trump won the presidency despite losing the popular vote by nearly 3 million votes. This discrepancy raises concerns about the democratic legitimacy of the Electoral College and the extent to which it truly represents the preferences of the American people.

Moreover, the Electoral College has been criticized for its potential to disenfranchise certain groups of voters, particularly those living in states that consistently vote for one party or the other. In these so-called "safe states," voters may feel that their votes do not matter since the outcome is largely predetermined. This can lead to lower voter turnout and a diminished sense of civic engagement among citizens in these states.

In light of these criticisms, there have been calls for the abolition of the Electoral College and the adoption of a popular vote system for presidential elections. Proponents of this change argue that it would ensure that every vote counts equally and that the President would always be elected by the majority of the population. They also contend that a popular vote system would encourage candidates to focus on national issues and policies rather than catering to the interests of specific states or regions.

In conclusion, the Electoral College remains a controversial and multifaceted aspect of American democracy. While it has been praised for its ability to protect the interests of smaller states and promote stability in the political system, it has also been criticized for its potential to produce outcomes that do not reflect the will of the majority and for disenfranchising certain groups of voters. As the debate over the Electoral College continues, it is crucial to carefully consider the strengths and weaknesses of this system and to evaluate whether it truly serves the best interests of American democracy and its citizens.

In the bustling metropolis of the 21st century, a revolutionary concept has emerged, challenging the traditional dominance of automobiles: car-free cities. This forward-thinking approach aims to reclaim urban spaces from the grip of vehicles, prioritizing the well-being of residents and the environment. While some may view this vision as utopian or impractical, a closer examination reveals the compelling arguments in favor of creating car-free cities.

One of the primary benefits of car-free cities is the significant reduction in air pollution. Vehicles, particularly those powered by fossil fuels, are major contributors to greenhouse gas emissions. By eliminating cars from urban areas, cities can dramatically improve air quality, reducing the incidence of respiratory illnesses and creating a healthier living environment for all.

Furthermore, car-free cities promote sustainable transportation alternatives, fostering a shift towards walking, cycling, and public transit. This not only reduces traffic congestion, but also encourages physical activity and healthier lifestyles. With more people opting for non-motorized transportation, cities become more vibrant and livable, with wider sidewalks, bike lanes, and pedestrian-friendly plazas.

Moreover, car-free cities offer a unique opportunity to reclaim public spaces for community use. By removing cars from streets and parking lots, cities can create more green spaces, parks, and plazas, providing residents with places to socialize, relax, and enjoy the outdoors. This transformation enhances the overall livability of cities, making them more attractive and enjoyable places to live, work, and visit.

In addition to the environmental and health benefits, car-free cities also have a positive impact on the local economy. By reducing the need for car ownership and parking infrastructure, cities can free up valuable land for other uses, such as housing, businesses, and community facilities. This can stimulate economic growth and create new job opportunities. Furthermore, car-free cities often attract tourists and businesses seeking a more sustainable and vibrant urban environment.

While the transition to car-free cities may require significant investment and effort, the long-term benefits are undeniable. By embracing this transformative concept, cities can create a healthier, more sustainable, and more livable future for their residents. The success of car-free cities, such as Copenhagen, Freiburg, and Bogotá, demonstrates the viability and desirability of this approach. As more cities around the world embrace the car-free model, we can pave the way for a future where our urban spaces are designed for people, not for cars.

The United States' presidential election system is unique in that it relies on the Electoral College rather than the direct popular vote. This system, established in the Constitution, has been a subject of ongoing debate, with arguments both for and against its continued use. While the Electoral College has several advantages, it also has significant drawbacks that raise questions about its effectiveness in ensuring a fair and democratic election process.

One of the main arguments in favor of the Electoral College is that it protects the interests of small states. In a direct popular vote system, large states with dense populations would have a disproportionate influence on the outcome of the election, potentially marginalizing the voices of voters in smaller states. The Electoral College, with each state's electors weighted according to its population, ensures that all states have a say in the election. This can be seen as a safeguard for the federalist system of government, where each state retains a certain degree of autonomy.

Another argument for the Electoral College is that it prevents candidates from winning the presidency without broad support across the country. In a direct popular vote system, a candidate could potentially win the presidency by securing a majority of votes in a few large states, ignoring the needs and concerns of voters in other parts of the country. The Electoral College, however, requires a candidate to win a majority of electoral votes, which are distributed among the states based on population. This encourages candidates to campaign in a wider range of states, ensuring that they have support from a diverse electorate.

However, there are also strong arguments against the Electoral College system. One of the most significant criticisms is that it can lead to a situation where a candidate wins the presidency without winning the popular vote. This has happened five times in U.S. history, most recently in 2016 when Donald Trump defeated Hillary Clinton in the Electoral College despite losing the popular vote by nearly 3 million votes. This outcome has led to accusations that the Electoral College is undemocratic and undermines the principle of "one person, one vote."

Another criticism of the Electoral College is that it gives disproportionate power to swing states, which are states that are closely divided between the two major parties. In these states, a small number of votes can make a big difference in the outcome of the election. This can lead to candidates focusing their campaigns almost exclusively on swing states, while ignoring the needs of voters in states that are considered safe for one party or the other. This phenomenon, known as the "swing state effect," can result in a distorted representation of the national electorate.

Additionally, the Electoral College system can make it difficult for third-party candidates to compete effectively. In a direct popular vote system, third-party candidates would have a chance of winning if they could secure a significant number of votes nationwide. However, in the Electoral College system, third-party candidates face an uphill battle because they need to win a majority of electoral votes in individual states, which is often very difficult to achieve. This can lead to a two-party system where third-party candidates are marginalized and have little influence on the outcome of the election.

In conclusion, the Electoral College system has both advantages and disadvantages. While it protects the interests of small states and encourages candidates to campaign in a wider range of states, it can also lead to outcomes where a candidate wins the presidency without winning the popular vote, gives disproportionate power to swing states, and makes it difficult for third-party candidates to compete effectively. Whether the Electoral College is an effective system for electing the president of the United States is a matter of ongoing debate. There are strong arguments on both sides of the issue, and it is ultimately up to the American people to decide whether this system should be maintained or reformed.

Dear State Senator, I propose that we change the election by popular vote for the president of the United States rather than having the Electoral College. I say this because the Electoral College is unfair to voters in many ways more than one.

I'll start off by saying that Electoral College is unfair to voters. If you can't or don't know who they are voting for, then how can we trust them with the fate of our country? To continue my agreement, the Electoral College is also unfair in this way. Say if there was to be a tie in electoral votes, the election would be given to the House of Representatives.
